questions.text: The uterine artery crosses the ureter ______
questions.solution: The uterine artery crosses the ureter anteriorly (Water under the bridge). Damage to the ureter is more likely at this site (most dangerous site) during hysterectomy.

questions.text: A newborn child was noted to have a congenital anomaly as shown in the image below. All of the following  statements are true about this condition except:

choices.text: Closure of abdominal wall should be done within the first year
Bilateral inguinal hernia is seen in males

questions.solution:
The congenital anomaly seen in the above image is exstrophy of the bladder (ectopia vesicae). It is associated with epispadias, not hypospadias.

Bladder exstrophy refers to herniation of the urinary bladder through an anterior abdominal wall defect. The bladder is open and exposed on the outside of the abdomen. The male to female ratio is 4:1. Chronic exposure of the bladder to the external environment can lead to adenocarcinoma of the bladder. 

The clinical features of bladder exstrophy include:

  • Separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis
  • Epispadias
  • In males: Broad and short penis and bilateral inguinal hernia 
  • In females: Bifid clitoris 

Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. Closure of the abdominal and bladder wall is done in the first year of life. This often requires an iliac osteotomy to relax the tension on the bladder and repair the abdominal wall during wound-healing.

Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects is done.

questions.text: A young girl presents with continuous dribbling of urine but she voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with continuous dribbling of urine, in spite of regular voiding, is suggestive of an ectopic ureter.

Ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly that occurs as a result of abnormal caudal migration of the ureteral bud during its insertion into the urinary bladder. They are usually associated with duplex ureters and drain from the upper pole of the kidney.

It is more common in females. The ectopic ureter usually opens into the urethra, vagina, and perineum. Hence, female patients present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly (Paradoxical incontinence). It can cause hydroureteronephrosis and recurrent UTI.

In males, the ectopic ureter opens always above the external urethral sphincter.  Hence they are usually continent. However, it can cause other complications such as orchitis and epididymitis.

Management involves re-implantation of the ureter into the bladder to treat incontinence and preserve renal functions. If the kidney is severely affected, partial nephrectomy is helpful.

questions.text: During a cricket match, a batsman controls his urge to urinate as he is unable to take a break in-between. While batting, he suffers a sudden blow as the ball hits him in the suprapubic region. He presents to the emergency department with severe hypogastric pain and the inability to pass urine. He collapses suddenly during the examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of injury to a full bladder, inability to pass urine, and syncope are suggestive of intraperitoneal rupture of the bladder.

Bladder rupture can be of two types:

  Extraperitoneal rupture Intraperitoneal rupture
  More common (80%)  Less common (20%)
Cause
  • Penetrating trauma
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Surgical damage
  • Associated with proximal urethral injury
  
  • Direct blow or fall on a distended bladder
Clinical features
  • Pelvic urinoma (encapsulated collection of extravasated urine) is seen
  • Blood at the tip of the meatus
  • Sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium
  • Syncope
  • Peritonitis
 
Treatment
  • Catheter drainage for 7–10 days
  • Laparotomy
  • Repair of bladder
  • Bladder drainage
 


Pubic diastasis refers to the separation of the pubic symphysis without concomitant fracture. Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture usually occurs due to straddle injury and presents with blood at the tip of the meatus.

questions.text: A patient was rushed to the casualty after sustaining a suprapubic injury. On examination, no blood is seen at the meatus. On inserting Foley’s catheter, gross hematuria is noted. His vitals are stable and his pelvic X-ray is given below. What will be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a bladder injury. Open book fracture is most likely suggestive of an intraperitoneal bladder injury. CT cystogram will be the next step in the management to confirm the type of bladder injury. In unstable patients, a cystogram will be the investigation of choice.

If an associated urethral injury is suspected, retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is done.

Note: Closed book pelvic fractures are more commonly associated with urethral injuries than bladder injuries.

questions.text: An elderly man was rushed to the casualty at midnight with complaints of severe suprapubic pain and inability to pass urine for the past 24 hours. The abdominal examination finding of the patient is given below. A smooth and enlarged prostate was felt in the per-rectal examination. While attempting to insert a 16-F Foley catheter in this patient, you feel resistance and fail to catheterize. What will be the next step in the management?

choices.text: Insert a smaller sized Foley catheter

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute retention of urine, possibly because of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The next step would be to insert an 18-Fr Coudé catheter.

In men, the BPH especially the middle lobe enlargement obstructs the insertion of Foley's catherter. Hence, a Coude catheter is advised over suprapubic catetherization as the immediate next step as larger Fr Coude catheter is helpful in negotiating past the angulation in the prostatic urethra. 

(Note: In acute urine retention, urethral strictures should be suspected when there is resistance at the urethral meatus as the strictures are more common in distal urethra than proximal urethra)

Bladder outlet obstruction is usually the most common cause of acute retention of urine. Its clinical features include:

  • Inability to pass urine
  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • A distended, palpable, and tender bladder

Acute urinary retention is managed by placing a urethral catheter as early as possible. Usually in BPH, smaller catheters will not pass through the angulation of the prostatic urethra as they are flexible and kink. Hence in BPH, the Coudé-tip catheter, which has a rigid and angulated tip, can be used to overcome the urethral obstruction.

If urethral catheter placement is not successful, suprapubic catheterization should be done. 

If there is a urethral stricture, a council tip catheter is used to dilate it using a cystoscope, guide wires, and urethral dilators.

questions.text: You are asked to remove a Foley’s catheter after a procedure but you are unable to deflate the balloon. The surgeon himself tries to remove it after cutting the sidearm but is unsuccessful as well. What should be the next step of management?

choices.text: CT-guided rupture of bulb of Foley's
Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
Inject water to over distend the balloon until it bursts and remove the catheter
Inflate with 20ml of water and under USG guidance, locate and prick the balloon

questions.solution:
USG-guided rupture of the balloon percutaneously after inflating it with 20ml water should be the next step of management.

The failure of the balloon to deflate may be caused by:

  • Faulty valve mechanism 
  • Blockage of the inflation channel by debris
  • Crystallization of the fluid within the balloon (when saline is used)

The next best step in the management of a retained Foley's catheter is to further inflate the balloon with 20mL of water, following which the inflated balloon is ruptured percutaneously with a needle under USG guidance. 

A suprapubic approach is used in males, while in females, either a transurethral or transvaginal route can be used. A cystoscopy should be done to ensure that all fragments are removed.

Other methods of approach include cutting the sidearm of the catheter, thereby disabling the valve mechanism, or advancing a ureteric stylet or fine-gauge wire through the inflation port to dislodge debris or puncture the balloon. But these are often unsuccessful.

Option A: CT is not routinely used in most settings with retained Foley's.

Option B: Injection of ether through the balloon port causes the rupture of the balloon within seconds. But this technique causes significant bladder irritation.

Option C: Balloons should not be overinflated until they rupture. This may cause severe pain and could cause bladder rupture.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: In the given picture of a Foley’s catheter, what is the function of the tube marked ‘A’?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a three-way Foley's catheter. The tube marked ‘A’ is used for continuous irrigation of the bladder to remove debris & blood clots. This is most commonly used after any prostate surgery or conditions with bleeding in the bladder.

The central tube is used for the drainage of urine and the tube on the right is used for inflating the balloon.

questions.text: What is the earliest sign seen on cystoscopy in a patient suspected to have bladder tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is the pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.

In long-standing cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced (thimble bladder). This is managed by augmentation cystoplasty.

The following X-ray KUB shows a thimble bladder:


Ureteric lesions can also be seen in genitourinary tuberculosis. They include:

  • Kerr’s kink - kinking of the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ)
  • Ureteral stricture
  • Beaded ureter
  • Shortening of the ureter
  • Golf hole ureter - Longitudinal fibrosis leading to shortening of the ureter and pulling up the orifice as a gaping hole. Reimplantation of ureter is done.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes with complaints of hematuria and difficulty in urination for the past few weeks. Microscopic examination of urine samples shows parasitic eggs as shown in the image. Which type of bladder carcinoma is the patient most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of schistosomiasis. The patient is most likely to develop squamous cell carcinoma as it is associated with schistosomiasis. The image shows oval-shaped eggs with the terminal spine which is characteristic of Schistosoma haematobium. 

Schistosomal bladder cancers can also be adenocarcinoma or transitional cell carcinoma (less frequently).

Primary bladder tumors usually originate from the transitional epithelium of the bladder (90%). Sometimes, they arise from connective tissue. Secondary tumors of the bladder arise from the sigmoid and rectum, the prostate, the uterus, or the ovaries. 

Carcinoma of the bladder & associated risk factors: 

Histological subtype Risk factors
Transitional cell carcinoma (urothelial)
  • Smoking
  • Exposure to aniline dyes
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Pelvic irradiation

Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Schistosomiasis
  • Chronic irritation caused by stone disease
  • Bladder diverticula
  • Chronic UTI
  • Smoking
Adenocarcinoma
  • Persistent urachus or trigone of the bladder

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes carcinoma bladder?
questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide (an alkylating agent) causes bladder cancer

The risk of bladder cancer with cyclophosphamide is directly proportional to the duration and intensity of cyclophosphamide treatment. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenic metabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide.

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. 

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma can be divided into 

  1. Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  2. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (70% of cases) - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. 
  3. Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis is by cystourethroscopy (directly visualizing the growth) and biopsy. Management is as follows: 

  1. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer:
    1. Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical chemotherapy with mitomycin C or epirubicin
    2. Immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG) in high-risk tumors.
  2. Muscle invasive bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options:

Option B: Cisplatin is an anticancer drug used to treat testicular cancer. It is associated with an increased risk for acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Option C: Taxane is an anticancer drug and is the main component in the treatment regimens of metastatic cancers. Taxane's adverse effects are neutropenia and fluid retention (pulmonary edema).

Option D: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and is used in the treatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancer. Due to its partial agonistic activity, it is known to increase endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding bladder carcinoma.

choices.text: Painless hematuria is the most common symptom
Inactivation of the Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation
The most important prognostic factor is the size of the tumor

questions.solution:
The most important prognostic factor in bladder carcinoma is the depth of invasion. 

Activation of oncogenes such as ras, c-erbB, E2F3, and inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes such as p53, p21, p16, and Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation of the bladder.

Clinical features of bladder carcinoma include:

  • Painless gross haematuria - Most common symptom and is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise
  • Urinary retention
  • Constant pelvic pain
  • Increased urinary frequency
  • Discomfort while urinating
  • If there is nerve involvement, pain is referred to the suprapubic region, groins, perineum, and thighs.

Investigations done for bladder cancer are:

  • Urine cytology - Low sensitivity
  • Intravenous urography - Not frequently used nowadays. Replaced by non-contrast CT and MRI
  • Cystourethroscopy and biopsy - The best investigation

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a patient with non-invasive bladder carcinoma of stage pT1?

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumor

questions.solution:
Since the pathological staging of the tumor is given (pT1), it implies that transurethral resection of the bladder tumor (TURBT) has already been done. Therefore, this patient should be managed by instillation of intravesical BCG.

TURBT is done for the pathologic staging of the tumor. This staging helps us to decide the further plan of treatment. Intravesical therapy (using chemotherapy or immunotherapy) is done within 24hrs of TURBT in order to kill any residual cancer cells. It only affects the lining of the bladder and is not useful for cancers that have spread into the deeper layers.

pT stage: Pathological stage

pT stage Extent of the tumor
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
Ta Noninvasive papillary carcinoma
Tis Carcinoma in situ
T1 Tumor invades subepithelial connective tissue (lamina propria)
T2 Tumor invades muscularis propria bladder wall
T3 Tumor invades perivesical tissue
T4 Tumor invades any of the following: Prostate, uterus, vagina, pelvic wall and abdominal wall

 

Treatment of carcinoma bladder:

pT stage Treatment
  • Low-grade pTa
 Intravesical chemotherapy with mitomycin, thiotepa, and adriamycin may be started after TURBT
  • High-grade pTa
  • pTis
  • pT1 
 Intravesical BCG is started after TURBT
  • pT2
 Radical cystectomy followed by radiotherapy
  • pT3
  • pT4
 Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (M-VAC), radical cystectomy, and radiotherapy


M-VAC chemotherapy regime consists of:

  • Methotrexate
  • Vinblastine
  • Adriamycin
  • Cisplatin

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma in situ of the urinary bladder is posted for intravesical therapy. What is the strain of mycobacteria that will be used in this therapy?
questions.solution:
An attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis is used in intravesical BCG therapy.

Intravesical BCG is used for the treatment of non-invasive (no invasion into the muscle layer) urinary bladder tumors. It induces a strong local inflammatory response against the attenuated bacteria, which helps in the destruction of the tumor cells.

Option d: Mw vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii. It is also used as an adjunct to chemotherapy for category II tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which laser is preferred for performing transurethral resection of the bladder tumor?
questions.solution:
The Nd: YAG laser is preferred for the resection of minimally invasive bladder tumors.

questions.text: An elderly man on follow-up for treatment of bladder cancer presents with painless hematuria. Which of the following assays should be done on this patient?
questions.solution:
An NMP 22 assay should be done in this patient to detect the recurrence of bladder carcinoma. 

NMP 22 is a nuclear matrix protein that is used to form cell nuclei. It is shed into the urine and has a higher concentration in the urine of bladder cancer patients. NMP-22 cutoff levels for bladder cancer detection is > 10 units/mL.

questions.text: Urinary diversion is indicated in all the following clinical conditions, except:
questions.solution:
Urinary diversion is not done in cases of bladder hematoma. 

Urinary diversion procedures are performed to divert urine from the bladder to a new exit site. It is of two types:

  • Cutaneous urinary diversion (External diversion): Urine drains through an opening created in the abdominal wall and skin
    • Ileal conduit - urine is diverted by implanting ureters into a loop of ileum that is led out through the abdominal wall.
    • Cutaneous ureterostomy - ureters are directed through the abdominal wall and attached to an opening in the skin.
  • Continent urinary diversion (Internal urinary diversion): A portion of the intestine is used to create a new reservoir for urine. The internal pouch is placed inside the abdomen. The ureters are attached to the internal pouch, and the internal pouch is attached to the urethra or to a stoma in the abdomen with a valve.

Indications of urinary diversion:

  • Post cystectomy
  • Carcinoma of the urinary bladder
  • Distal obstruction
  • Neurogenic bladder
  • Ectopia vesicae, Incurable fistula
  • Irremovable obstruction
  • Trauma to the ureters and urethra

questions.text:
A patient presents to the emergency department with confusion and drowsiness. He underwent cystectomy with urinary diversion for bladder carcinoma 8 weeks back. ABG analysis and electrolyte values are given below. Which of the following urinary diversion conduits was most likely done in this patient?

pH - 7.20

PaO2 - 12.3

PaCO2 - 4.5

HCO3 - 12

Serum potassium - 1.9 mEq/l

Chloride - 111 mEq/l
questions.solution:
A uretero-sigmoid diversion was most likely done in this patient as it frequently results in hyperchloremic hypokalemic acidosis. Hypokalemia is less common with ileal diversions because the ileum reabsorbs some of the potassium from the urine while the colon does not.

The order in which the hyperchloraemic hypokalemic acidosis occurs is sigmoid colon > colon/ileum.

Electrolyte abnormalities based on the part of intestine involved:
 
Stomach   Jejunum Ileum/colon
Hypokalemia   Hyperkalemia Hypokalemia
Hypochloremia Hypochloremia Hyperchloremia
Metabolic alkalosis Metabolic acidosis Metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady experiences increased frequency of urination and lower abdominal pain which is relieved by micturition. Urinalysis is normal. Cystoscopy reveals fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with normal urinalysis and cystoscopy findings are suggestive of interstitial cystitis.

Interstitial cystitis is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, occurring most frequently in women. It is also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome. Its clinical features include:

  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • Urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Hematuria
  • Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection

Cystoscopic findings seen in bladder mucosa are:

  • Fissures
  • Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations)
  • Ulcerations in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer)

The image shows Hunner's ulcer seen in interstitial cystitis:

Treatment options include :

  • Conservative - Patient education about the chronicity of the condition, behavioral modification (timed voiding, bladder training), stress reduction, dietary alteration (avoidance of caffeine and spicy and acidic foods) and physical therapy should be the initial management for all patients.
  • Pharmacological - Neuropathic analgesics (e.g. amitriptyline, pregabalin) are used for those with a significant pain component, whereas antimuscarinics and β3-agonists are used for frequency, nocturia and urgency symptoms.
  • Surgical - For those with Hunner lesions, fulguration or laser to these lesions can be beneficial. Cystodistension as a treatment has variable evidence for success. If these options fail to improve symptoms major surgical reconstruction can be considered in selected cases.

Option b: Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It appears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques.

Option d: Cystitis cystica occurs due to chronic irritation of the bladder mucosa. Cystoscopy reveals cystic lesions in the bladder.

questions.text: A child with recurrent urinary tract infection undergoes voiding cystourethrogram. It shows reflux of urine into the pelvis and calyces, without dilation of the ureter. What is the grade of vesicoureteric reflux?
questions.solution:
Reflux of urine into pelvis and calyces without dilatation is Grade II vesicoureteric reflux (VUR).

VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract. VUR is a common clinical entity. The investigation of choice for VUR is micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

VUR is graded as follows:

 GRADE DESCRIPTION
I Reflux into a non-dilated ureter
II Reflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilatation of the ureter
III Reflux is associated with mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, with minimal blunting of the fornices
IV Moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces
V Gross dilatation of the ureter, pelvis, and calyses; loss of papillary impressions; ureteral  tortuosity

questions.text: Which of the following will be seen in a patient with Marion’s disease?

choices.text: Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder
Hypertrophy of the external sphincter of the bladder
Congenital obstruction of the prostatic urethra

questions.solution:
Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder is seen in Marion’s disease. This leads to bladder outlet obstruction. Its clinical features include voiding and storage symptoms (usually associated with BPH). Therefore it is also called prostatism sans prostate:

  • Increased urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Dribbling of urine
  • Hesitancy
  • Intermittent stream
  • Nocturia

It is commonly seen in young patients.

Bladder outlet obstruction can occur due to 2 causes:

  • Muscular causes
    • Congenital hypertrophy of internal sphincter, i.e., Marion's disease
    • Dyssynergic contraction of the smooth muscle of the bladder neck (bladder neck dyssynergia)
  • Fibrosis of bladder neck following transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the condition shown below?

choices.text: Bilateral in more than 50% of the cases
Affects males more often than females

questions.solution:
The given intravenous urography (IVU) image depicts cobra head/adder head deformity which is a classic sign of ureterocele. It is associated with dysplastic renal tissue.

Ureterocele:

A ureterocele is the cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter. It is thought to be caused due to ureteric orifice atresia. It is observed more in females than males in a 4:1 preponderance and is bilateral in about 10% of the cases. They are similar to ectopic ureters wherein the upper pole of the kidney is drained. This condition is typically associated with dysplastic and non-functional renal tissue.

Clinical presentation:

  • Children with ureterocele usually present with infection.
  • Adults present with renal stones.

Diagnosis:

  • IVU shows a classical cobra head sign but is relatively infrequently performed these days.
  • Cystoscopy shows a bulging, translucent swelling involving the ureteric orifice where there is urinary stasis. It is emptied by ureteric peristalsis.

Treatment:

  • Surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter is the treatment of choice for simple ureterocele.
  • Renal stones associated with ureterocele are removed using an endoscopic incision
  • An advanced disease that causes hydronephrosis or pyonephrosis is an indication for nephrectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding bladder stone is false?

choices.text: Primary bladder stone develops in sterile urine
Uric acid stones occur  in patients with ileostomies
Triple phosphate calculus  occurs in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

questions.solution:
A cystine calculus occurs only in the presence of cystinuria and is radioopaque because of its high sulfur content.

Primary bladder stone:

  • Develops in sterile urine in the absence of any known functional, anatomic, or infectious factors and does not necessarily imply that stones have formed de novo in the bladder.
  • Most common in children younger than 10 years of age
  • Most vesical calculi are mixed
  • Ammonium acid urate, calcium oxalate, uric acid, and calcium phosphate are the most common components of primary bladder calculi

Secondary bladder stone: Forms during infection, due to bladder outflow obstruction, impaired bladder emptying, or the presence of a foreign body.

Types:

  • Calcium oxalate stones
  • Uric acid stones - occur in patients with gout but are also observed in patients with ileostomies or with bladder outlet obstruction
  • Cystine stones - in cystinuria
  • Triple phosphate stones - occur in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.
